org.vertx.java.core.http

Class HttpServer

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.vertx.java.core.net.NetBase
      • org.vertx.java.core.net.NetServerBase
        • org.vertx.java.core.http.HttpServer

  • public class HttpServer
extends NetServerBase

    An HTTP server.

    The server supports both HTTP requests and HTML5 websockets and passes these to the user via the appropriate handlers.

    An HttpServer instance can only be used from the event loop that created it.

    Author:
    Tim Fox

      • requestHandler

        public HttpServer requestHandler(Handler<HttpServerRequest> requestHandler)
        Set the request handler for the server to requestHandler. As HTTP requests are received by the server, instances of HttpServerRequest will be created and passed to this handler.
        Returns:
        a reference to this, so methods can be chained.

      • requestHandler

        public Handler<HttpServerRequest> requestHandler()
        Get the request handler
        Returns:
        The request handler

      • websocketHandler

        public HttpServer websocketHandler(WebSocketHandler wsHandler)
        Set the websocket handler for the server to wsHandler. If a websocket connect handshake is successful a new WebSocket instance will be created and passed to the handler.
        Returns:
        a reference to this, so methods can be chained.

      • setSSL

        public HttpServer setSSL(boolean ssl)
        If ssl is true, this signifies that any connections will be SSL connections.
        Overrides:
        setSSL in class NetBase
        Returns:
        A reference to this, so multiple invocations can be chained together.

      • setKeyStorePath

        public HttpServer setKeyStorePath(java.lang.String path)
        Set the path to the SSL key store. This method should only be used in SSL mode, i.e. after NetBase.setSSL(boolean) has been set to true.

        The SSL key store is a standard Java Key Store, and, if on the server side will contain the server certificate. If on the client side it will contain the client certificate. Client certificates are only required if the server requests client authentication.

        Overrides:
        setKeyStorePath in class NetBase
        Returns:
        A reference to this, so multiple invocations can be chained together.

      • setKeyStorePassword

        public HttpServer setKeyStorePassword(java.lang.String pwd)
        Set the password for the SSL key store. This method should only be used in SSL mode, i.e. after NetBase.setSSL(boolean) has been set to true.

        Overrides:
        setKeyStorePassword in class NetBase
        Returns:
        A reference to this, so multiple invocations can be chained together.

      • setTrustStorePath

        public HttpServer setTrustStorePath(java.lang.String path)
        Set the path to the SSL trust store. This method should only be used in SSL mode, i.e. after NetBase.setSSL(boolean) has been set to true.

        The trust store is a standard Java Key Store, and, if on the server side it should contain the certificates of any clients that the server trusts - this is only necessary if client authentication is enabled. If on the client side, it should contain the certificates of any servers the client trusts. If you wish the client to trust all server certificates you can use the NetClientBase.setTrustAll(boolean) method.

        Overrides:
        setTrustStorePath in class NetBase
        Returns:
        A reference to this, so multiple invocations can be chained together.

      • setTrustStorePassword

        public HttpServer setTrustStorePassword(java.lang.String pwd)
        Set the password for the SSL trust store. This method should only be used in SSL mode, i.e. after NetBase.setSSL(boolean) has been set to true.

        Overrides:
        setTrustStorePassword in class NetBase
        Returns:
        A reference to this, so multiple invocations can be chained together.

      • setClientAuthRequired

        public HttpServer setClientAuthRequired(boolean required)
        Set required to true if you want the server to request client authentication from any connecting clients. This is an extra level of security in SSL, and requires clients to provide client certificates. Those certificates must be added to the server trust store.
        Overrides:
        setClientAuthRequired in class NetServerBase
        Returns:
        A reference to this, so multiple invocations can be chained together.

      • setTcpNoDelay

        public HttpServer setTcpNoDelay(boolean tcpNoDelay)
        If tcpNoDelay is set to true then Nagle's algorithm will turned off for the TCP connections created by this instance.
        Overrides:
        setTcpNoDelay in class NetBase
        Returns:
        a reference to this so multiple method calls can be chained together

      • close

        public void close()
        Close the server. Any open HTTP connections will be closed.

      • close

        public void close(Handler<java.lang.Void> done)
        Close the server. Any open HTTP connections will be closed. doneHandler will be called when the close is complete.
